segments.text: Testing.
This is an interview with Dr. John H. Milleth.
Today's date is February 25th, 1980.
This is an interview with the veterinarian project and this is Terry Anderson.
This is a test.
This is an interview with Dr. John Milleth on February 25, 1980.
This is Terry Anderson.
Could you tell us where and when you were born?
I was born in Batesville, Arkansas in 1903.
Can you tell us about your parents, their occupation?
Well, my father was born in Bowling Green, Kentucky.
His father was from Ireland.
Came over here at the time of the potato famine in Ireland.
In the 1840s.
And settled in Kentucky, married there, and had the, well, he was married twice.
He had a larger family with the first marriage, and then with the second marriage, my father had only the one child.
After my father was born, I don't believe that his father lived very much longer after that.
But dad had to begin work at an early age.
So he missed out on his schooling.
He began as a water boy and just sort of worked his way up.
He was with the US engineers on river work on Green River in Kentucky.
Then in later years, he was down in Arkansas, where I was born, putting in a lock and dam on White River.
Oh, really?
Yeah.
Is this part of the Bull Shoals?
I don't know.
I've never been back.
So it wasn't too far from Batesville, because we lived in Batesville, and he went back and forth.
In the Ozarks, yeah.
Yeah.

and from there he was transferred back to Kentucky to do some work on Green River and then from there to Texas to work on the Brazos River cleaning out overhanging timbers and blasting out log jams and what have you.
This was down around San Philippi and Seeley.
We lived in Seeley at the time, Seeley, Texas.
And when that was completed we were
transferred to Navasota, Texas.
And he put in the Lock and Dam in the Brazos out from Navasota.
He was the superintendent of construction by that time.
But even though he had never been to school a day in his life, he learned from the engineers who were on the job.
He studied their books and so on.
His job actually was to handle men.
And he knew how to handle men.
So from Navasota, where I began school in 1910, we were transferred to Ferris, Texas.
He had some repair work to do on the locking dam out from Ferris in the Trinity River.
And from there down to Crockett.
to put in a locking dam in the Trinity River at Hurricane Shoal.
He was transferred after that to Port Arthur, Texas, to put in a locking dam there to keep the salt water off the rice farms.
And this was about 1917.
And my mother died that year.
And he gave up this work with the US engineers.
and began a farming life.
Really?
Yeah.
He said he'd had enough moving around, and we had moved with him everywhere he went.
Mother was tired of moving, too, and that's the reason we settled in Crockett.
She said she wasn't going to move anymore.
And he went to Port Arthur by himself and would come home at Christmas and so on, any other vacation time he had.
She died that year, 1917.
But tell me about her.
She was an old Kentucky girl.
Her name was Bobbitt, B-O-B-B-I-T-T, Rosella Bobbitt.
I don't know much of her family.
Of course, I was supposed to have seen them when we went from Arkansas back to Kentucky, but I was too young to remember anything about it.
I've never kept up with her side of the family.
I don't know, she had some sisters, she had some brothers and so on, but whatever became of them, I don't know.
What did she die of?
She had peritonitis.
It was actually a miscarriage.
Oh, that's stupid.
And developed peritonitis from that.
So, we went
down on the farm with dad.
They were four boys and one girl.
And with my grandmother, that was my father's mother, she was with us.
And so this was an extensive farming project down there.
They had about 5,000 acres.
He had bought a farm when we first moved to Crockett, which was...
The farm was adjacent to the one that he bought half interest in in 1917.
So he ran both the farms.
I stayed with him until 1921, from 1917 to 1921.
That year was a bad farming year.
I had 100 acres in cotton on my own, and I think I picked about three bales.
It rained every day.
I raised beautiful crabgrass and all that.
Anyhow, I said, Dad, I'm leaving.
I wasn't going to school.
The years that I was on the farm, we were too far away from a school to go, and I had dropped out there in Crockett.
Well, I was supposed to have gone into the eighth grade,
And I dropped out.
So the people who owned the remainder of the ranch, Dave Nunn and his sister, Mrs. Curry, needed someone to help them.
They had a big home in Crockett, an old southern home, and had 15 cows that needed milking, a big yard, car, and house to clean, and so on.

I went there and they paid me $10 a week and gave me my room and board and I helped to milk the 15 cows morning and night and did the yard work and everything else that needed to be done around the place.
How old were you at that time?
Well, this was in 1921.
I was going on 18, yeah, when I went there.
Can we talk for a minute about this rice farm?
This is very interesting to me.
In 1917, your father's rice farm?
No.
He was transferred to Port Arthur to put in a lock down there to keep the water off of the rice farm.
Oh, okay.
Then what kind of farm did he have?
Well, we had sort of a combination farm.
We had all cotton and corn, and we had cattle and hogs and goats and such as that.
And did you say 5,000 acres?
Yeah, 5,000 acres in the Trinity River bottom in Houston County.
Oh, it extended from Old Alabama Ferry, which is across from Centerville, and on down, oh, I don't know, several miles on down the river toward Old Claps Ferry.
Now, did you have...

you had with your with your brothers did you have could you take care of the work yourself on the farm or did you have to hire out labor we had i don't have any families we had on the place dad built houses to for them and they lived and shared crops and so on and whenever he needed them where they did they labor for him oh i see so when i
They're both black and white.
Both black and white.
Yeah.
I guess we had around 20 families on the place, something like that.
But I went on school.
Right.
OK. Now, let's start that.
Your education.
Let's talk about your education in high school in Crockett, Texas.
What subjects did you like?
Well, I liked mathematics.
I liked mathematics, and I thought when I graduated in 1924, when I graduated from high school, I thought, well, electrical engineering was what I wanted.
Oh, I see.
So I came to A&M and signed up for double E. Oh, you did?
Oh, yeah.
Okay, that was another.
So that was when
Dr. Bolton was head of the department.
I stayed with it a year.
My background in high school was rather poor.
I thought I had had no chemistry.
I had good math courses, but no chemistry.
And that was one of my big weaknesses at A&M.
I had an awful time in chemistry.
Because in those days, in the chemistry department, you were begun with
students like my roommate, who had been to prep school.
And he had had chemistry.
And to him, it was just sort of a laughing matter.
To me, the first examination at the end of the first week, we had the lab quiz.
Give the chemical formula for the reagents on your desk.
I didn't know what H2O was.
This NH4OH and HCl and H2SO4 didn't mean anything to me.
And so that's the way it was from then on.
And valence was something else.
Dr. Brayton tried to straighten me out on valence.
You can imagine a couple dancing, and now they have two arms, and now they have three, and now they have four.
taking me a little fast.
Yeah, right.
I stayed with it until almost the end of the semester, just to get as much out of it as I could.
And two of the upperclassmen had already told me that no one expects to pass chemistry the first time they take it.
And so, of course, I didn't believe them.
But anyway, the second semester, I
I didn't have chemistry.
I took a course in plane surveying in place of it.
And at the end of that first year, I changed over to biology.
I left.
Why did you think you changed?
Mathematics was something that I didn't like at A&M.
But you liked it in high school.
I loved it because I had a lovely teacher.
She was an older person.
She was in her 60s and an old maid.
And she knew how to teach mathematics.
And I had plenty of time to study after I got through milking.
But I did all right in mathematics until I got into analytical geometry.
And they lost me on a parabola somewhere.
I don't know.
But there was an old boy teaching that course who was a graduate of University of Texas.
I don't know whether he had any love for the Aggies or not, but anyway, he was one of these dry, sour pussies, and whatever answer you gave just didn't satisfy him at all.
So I left it with him.
There were some things I liked.
I liked descriptive geometry and some other things, too.
But my biology, I thought, that's where I should be.
The English courses, I had no trouble with.
I guess at A&M, I made good grades in English all the way through and was selected as a member of the Junto

The J-U-N-T-O's, this was a select group of English students selected by Dr. or Mr. Thomas, Old Spot Thomas, we called him, and Tommy Mayo, who was librarian in the English department, an Oxford graduate.
Oh, really?
And they invited this select group of English students into their different homes in the English department.
So I enjoyed it very much.
But English to me has never been a bugaboo that it is to most A&M students and most students in general because of their poor background.
I often, I don't know how many times I've talked to Tommy Mayo.
Tommy, why do we have all of this literature, all this reading and so on in English at A&M and in other colleges as well?
You start off with composition and rhetoric and so on.
Why don't we begin with just plain old English grammar?
The only English grammar I had was in the seventh grade.
And at that age, it didn't mean anything to me.
What's a compound sentence or complex or compound complex or simple sentence?
And usually at A&M,
The only time a student knows that he has a sentence, he finds a period.
And that's about it.
I was, just as an aside, I visited most of the courses in modern language.
Oh, you did?
When was this?
Oh, this was during my years as a teacher.
I had French and German and Russian, four years and so on.
Well, I was in German, in one German class, and the professor, Mr. Stadelman, he was from Hitler, Germany.
He left there to get away from Hitler.
So he was here teaching German.
He asked one of the students, what is a gerund?
And this English student didn't know.
Since I was a visitor, I wasn't supposed to enter into the conversation anyway.
I just sat and listened.
The only person in the class who knew what a gerund was was a Chinaman, a Chinese student.
Really?
Told him what a gerund is.
Probably because he learned English overseas.
He learned his English.
He learned grammar.
Well, that's been the case in A&M.
And I think you can say it's that way in all universities.
They need a good course in grammar, English grammar.
But if they ever got it in high school or grammar school, probably they've forgotten it.
And consequently, most college students are poor writers, poor spellers.
Yeah, I know that from correcting my essay exams.
Very poor.
Okay, so can you tell me, can you describe the Corps back when you were in the Corps in the mid-1920s at A&M?
Yeah, I can describe it very tersely.
That's all right.
The first thing they told me is fish.
You're here at A&M now.
Yes, sir.
You give your ass to the upperclassmen and your heart to God.
That's what they told you?
And that's about the way it was.
Really?
Well, I don't care.
You have to.
They'll hear you on tape.
That'll have to be deleted.
But anyway... No, but that was the idea.
That was the idea.
I was about five years older than the average run of students.
I was going on 21 when I graduated from high school.
Yeah.
So...
That sort of thing didn't set too well with me, all this hazing business, and they did haze.
And could you tell me about the hazing?
What types?
Anything.
Everything went.
For example?
Well, anything they wanted to beat your rear end with, they beat it with.
The Polo, Mallet, and what?
And they didn't pull any punches.
Sam Brown belts and wire hangers pulled out, coat hangers pulled out, split baseball bats, anything that they had.

And Dr. Bazell was president then, and he had just come here from the old CIA, and all the upperclassmen claiming he was trying to put lace on their drawers because he was trying to do away with hazing.
You were at the beck and call of the upperclassmen 24 hours a day.
I don't care if it was in the middle of the night and they wanted service, they got it.
2 o'clock in the morning, go over to the ice plane, get a chunk of ice, I want some ice water.
Or I'll be in at 4 o'clock on the morning train, you meet me there and pick up my suitcase.
Really?
Oh, everything went.
And...
Your rear end was black, and blue, and green, and yellow, and everything.
And finally, it got to be as hard as that wall, and rigid, and just ridges on it from whatever they beat you with.
Or an architect's triangular scale, you know what they are?
Yeah, yeah.
Right here.
Oh, yeah, they hurt.
And you put your leg across his, and he just starts, and you count.
And somewhere up there toward 100, while he loses, you lose count, so he said.
And he has to start all over again.
What was the rationale behind this punishment?
I often wondered.
Yeah.
I couldn't see anything.
Now, if I had misbehaved, if I were undisciplined and so on, I could see where somebody needed to give me some licks.
But just for it
general purpose, no way.
But by the time they got through that architect's gale, there'd be a place about the size of your hand, and it would be raised up about as thick as your hand and be black.
And when you walked, it felt as if it would fall out.
That would take you several weeks to get over that.
Or they'd take a straight pen.
and find a place that was not sensitive.
Really?
And just start pounding on that straight pin and driving on in.
No kidding.
Yeah.
I've had that done to my leg.
Oh, all manner of things that they did in those days.
Heaven help us.
But I guess that was the way of getting the Aggie spirit in you.
But...
Dr. Bazell, of course, clamped down on the hazing.
Well, it got to where you weren't supposed to hit a student with any kind of a board.
But nothing was said about exercise.
Nothing was said about exercise.
So you could do leaning rest.
And you could sit on infinity.
You know what sitting on infinity is?
Sitting on a board?
No.
Sitting on that?
The bayonet.
The bayonet, and you squat until you're seated on the point of that bayonet.
And then they take it out from under you, and you have to maintain that stance.
I mean, maintain it until you fall.
And by that time, sweat is running out of every pore on your body.
Or you stand, and you do this way.
Well, that goes all right for five or 10 minutes.
But you just keep on until you can't.
And you can't even hold your arms out.
And you're just perspiring.
You're wringing wet.
Try that.
And fish calls, duty calls, and we had
My roommate and I, old Stacy Siler, that old big fat boy, and I had two rooms to clean up.
The major's room next door and then an upperclassman's room around on the other side.
This was in old Milner Hall, second floor.
So all kinds of duties.
But I didn't mind that, cleaning up somebody's room along with your own.
because, golly, I had been cleaning house for four years through high school.
That was one of my jobs at the place where I was working.
Clean house and cook and wash dishes and anything else.
Make the fires in the morning, big old house.
They had four fireplaces and, golly, I don't have any cords of wood that would burn in the wintertime anyway.
Cleaning rooms didn't bother me and the people
The fellas in those rooms were very nice.
I did.
One of the fellas by the name of Gatlin is retired and at College Station now.
But Plebe Miller, the other one who was rooming with Gatlin, was expelled or, well, I guess he was suspended.
That freshman year, talking about hazing,

In order to get the freshmen in troop B cavalry on the line and get them ready to go over to Austin, Texas for Thanksgiving and play the University of Texas in the new stadium, this was to be the first game.
We were going to initiate that field over there, dedicate the stadium.
So they had to get us on the line.
They took us on what they call a pecan hunt.
Way out in here somewhere, this was all backwoods then, and they beat on us all Sunday afternoon.
I mean, anything they had.
Well, old Plebe was there, this Plebe Miller, was there, had a little piece of window sash rope, a little cotton rope, and he just tapped you a little bit, you know, you didn't feel it.
But anyway, 25 of our upperclassmen were suspended.
They were caught.
One of the fellas, the freshman, claimed he had an injury to his tailbone.
And so he went home.
And his father was in the state legislature.
And they had an investigation.
Big deal.
So 25 of the upperclassmen in B Troop were suspended or expelled.
I don't know which.
Anyway, Plebe was in the group.
But Plebe had been to Annapolis.
And in his sophomore year, he was expelled from Annapolis for hazing.
That's the reason they called him Plebe.
So he went home.
His family disowned him.
His gal, his girlfriend, quit him and all.
And he came back to A&M about the next week.
I awakened one morning, and Plebe was in my bunk with me, which was very unusual for an upperclassman to be bunking up with a
a freshman, a fish, and in those little narrow bunks.
Well, he stayed around about a week and went to Dallas and got him a room in a hotel and blew his brains out.
No kidding.
Yeah.
Killed himself on that.
Well, of course, we weren't very well pleased with the way it was handled.
The freshman, in spite of all of the
hazing and indecencies and what have you that upperclassmen did.
You would give your right arm for an upperclassman.
That was the bond between you, because even though they did haze you, they would do anything for you.
But you got discipline.
And I mean plenty of it.
Did you haze when you became an upperclassman?
No.
You didn't haze?
No.
I was against it.
But I didn't quit.
I took it.
Right along with the others.
No, I have a picture I want to show you.
It's just a negative, but this is my roommate.
I want to show you about Hayden.
You just sit there.
I'll bring it to you.
I had a print of this one, but I think you can tell from this negative, this was a black and white, you can tell the condition of his rear end.
Oh, my goodness.
He's had some boards go across that, it looks like.
Many of them.
Many of them.
This was old Stacy, who later became an MD and a surgeon.
That was his rear end.
Mine looked just like it at that time.
Really something.
You're going to have to put in a positive.
I didn't realize it was that .
I wouldn't get somebody to be upset.
These old boys here, both of these fellas, this was a fella by the name of Durst.
He was from Crockett.
Preacher, he was one of the Yale leaders in those days.
He was suspended along with that group.
And Buzz Gales was his roommate.
They were both suspended.
This old boy Durst became one of the vice presidents of Brown and Root.
No kidding.
He left two president scholars for A&M when he died.
That's the love that they had for A&M, even though they were treated that way.
Well, how can you account for that?
That's really interesting.
How can you account for the fact that these people were suspended and for the fact that you were hazed in sometimes a brutal fashion, and yet the respect and love for the institution is so profound?
That's right.
I would think that some people might be turned off by this.
Well, they were.
Some were turned off and they left.
I see.
Or either if they were misfits.
I remember one boy who was a misfit.
We packed him up and...
